text:
Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

With any type of sport, the participant naturally accepts or understands the possibility of injury and any other negative outcomes that may come from participating in said sport. For extreme mountain climbing, or any other type of extreme sport, the participant is aware of the risks involved and accepts them.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

With any type of sport, the participant naturally accepts or understands the possibility of injury and any other negative outcomes that may come from participating in said sport. For extreme mountain climbing, or any other type of extreme sport, the participant has to be still aware of the high risks involved, and accept them to a certain degree. For the most part, a grand majority of the population would steer clear of extreme sports, viewing the risks of the sports to be too high to be worthwhile, or the benefits too low to accept such risks.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? ---

For extreme mountain climbing, or any other type of extreme sport, the participant has to be still aware of the high risks involved, and accept them to a certain degree. For the most part, a grand majority of the population would steer clear of extreme sports, viewing the risks of the sports to be too high to be worthwhile, or the benefits too low to accept such risks. 

However, there are some people who are willing to accept the risks of extreme sports, and even take them to a higher level.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

With any type of sport, the participant naturally accepts or understands the possibility of injury and any other negative outcomes that may come from participating in said sport. For extreme mountain climbing, or any other type of extreme sport, the participant has to be still aware of the high risks involved, and accept them to a certain degree. For the most part, a grand majority of the population would steer clear of extreme sports, viewing the risks of the sports to be too high to be worthwhile, or the benefits too low to accept such risks. However, there are the notable few who are not only willing to accept the risks of extreme sports, but also take them to a higher level. These are the people that know what they are willing to risk, and are also willing to put in the effort and time to meet the demands of such sport, potentially even surpassing the records and achievements of past athletes.

Extreme sports are not for the faint of heart.

The risks of extreme sports are not only physical, but also mental.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

With any type of sport, the participant naturally accepts or understands the possibility of injury and any other negative outcomes that may come from participating in said sport. For extreme mountain climbing, or any other type of extreme sport, the participant has to be still aware of the high risks involved, and accept them to a certain degree. For the most part, a grand majority of the population would steer clear of extreme sports, viewing the risks of the sports to be too high to be worthwhile, or the benefits too low to accept such risks. However, there are the notable few who are not only willing to accept the risks of extreme sports, but also take them to a higher level. These are the people that know what they are willing to risk, and are also willing to put in the effort and time to meet the demands of such sport, potentially even surpassing the records and achievements of past athletes.

The risks of extreme sports are not only physical, but also mental. Thus, many have different considerations to make when deciding if a sport is reasonable or unreasonable to pursue. For that reason, I believe it is quite difficult to set a known standard for what makes a sport reasonable, that can essentially be applied to the everyone.

For that reason, I believe it is quite difficult to set a known standard for what makes a sport reasonable, that can essentially be applied to the everyone. For example, a person may be willing to risk their life for a sport, but not willing to risk their health.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

With any type of sport, the participant naturally accepts or understands the possibility of injury and any other negative outcomes that may come from participating in said sport. For extreme mountain climbing, or any other type of extreme sport, the participant has to be still aware of the high risks involved, and accept them to a certain degree. For the most part, a grand majority of the population would steer clear of extreme sports, viewing the risks of the sports to be too high to be worthwhile, or the benefits too low to accept such risks. However, there are the notable few who are not only willing to accept the risks of extreme sports, but also take them to a higher level. These are the people that know what they are willing to risk, and are also willing to put in the effort and time to meet the demands of such sport, potentially even surpassing the records and achievements of past athletes.

The risks of extreme sports are not only physical, but also mental. Thus, many have different considerations to make when deciding if a sport is reasonable or unreasonable to pursue. For that reason, I believe it is quite difficult to set a known standard for what makes a sport reasonable, that can essentially be applied to the everyone. For example, a person may be willing to risk their time and efforts for a less dangerous sport, but not willing to risk their health in terms of any injuries or debilitations they might sustain from participating in the sport. While one person might view a normal sport as too risky to play, another might view it as not risky enough to motivate them to participate in, nor to motivate them to improve their own abilities.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

With any type of sport, the participant naturally accepts or understands the possibility of injury and any other negative outcomes that may come from participating in said sport. For extreme mountain climbing, or any other type of extreme sport, the participant has to be still aware of the high risks involved, and accept them to a certain degree. For the most part, a grand majority of the population would steer clear of extreme sports, viewing the risks of the sports to be too high to be worthwhile, or the benefits too low to accept such risks. However, there are the notable few who are not only willing to accept the risks of extreme sports, but also take them to a higher level. These are the people that know what they are willing to risk, and are also willing to put in the effort and time to meet the demands of such sport, potentially even surpassing the records and achievements of past athletes.

The risks of extreme sports are not only physical, but also mental. Thus, many have different considerations to make when deciding if a sport is reasonable or unreasonable to pursue. For that reason, I believe it is quite difficult to set a known standard for what makes a sport reasonable, that can essentially be applied to the everyone. For example, a person may be willing to risk their time and efforts for a less dangerous sport, but not willing to risk their health in terms of any injuries or debilitations they might sustain from participating in the sport. While one person might view a normal sport as too risky to play, another might view it as not risky enough to motivate them to participate in, nor to motivate them to improve their own abilities. 

In my opinion, it is not the sport itself that makes it unreasonable, but rather the person's willingness to accept the risks involved.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

With any type of sport, the participant naturally accepts or understands the possibility of injury and any other negative outcomes that may come from participating in said sport. For extreme mountain climbing, or any other type of extreme sport, the participant has to be still aware of the high risks involved, and accept them to a certain degree. For the most part, a grand majority of the population would steer clear of extreme sports, viewing the risks of the sports to be too high to be worthwhile, or the benefits too low to accept such risks. However, there are the notable few who are not only willing to accept the risks of extreme sports, but also take them to a higher level. These are the people that know what they are willing to risk, and are also willing to put in the effort and time to meet the demands of such sport, potentially even surpassing the records and achievements of past athletes.

The risks of extreme sports are not only physical, but also mental. Thus, many have different considerations to make when deciding if a sport is reasonable or unreasonable to pursue. For that reason, I believe it is quite difficult to set a known standard for what makes a sport reasonable, that can essentially be applied to the everyone. For example, a person may be willing to risk their time and efforts for a less dangerous sport, but not willing to risk their health in terms of any injuries or debilitation they might sustain from participating in the sport. While one person might view a normal sport as too risky to play, another might view it as not risky enough to motivate them to participate in, nor to motivate them to improve their own abilities. In my opinion, it is not the sport itself and their risks that makes it unreasonable, but rather the person's willingness to accept the risks involved. Ultimately, there are a variety of people with different interests, abilities, and mindsets that affects how they view sports. A sport cannot be called too dangerous to be called a sport, as there always will exist the possibility that someone will rise up to the challenges of the sport, and set off to make notable accomplishments in the sport despite any risks that exist.

In any case, many high risk sports are likely to be viewed as unreasonable by those who prefer more traditional sports. That isn't to say some will view it as feasbile or impractical to pursue, but most will understand the dangers and steer clear based on their own vocation.

For that reason, I believe it is quite difficult to set a known standard for what makes a sport reasonable, that can essentially be applied to the everyone. For example, a person may be willing to risk their time and efforts for a less dangerous sport, but not willing to risk their health in terms of any injuries or debilitation they might sustain from participating in the sport. While one person might view a normal sport as too risky to play, another might view it as not risky enough to motivate them to participate in, nor to motivate them to improve their own abilities. In my opinion, it is not the sport itself and their risks that makes it unreasonable, but rather the person's willingness to accept the risks involved. Ultimately, there are a variety of people with different interests, abilities, and mindsets that affects how they view sports. A sport cannot be called too dangerous to be called a sport, as there always will exist the possibility that someone will rise up to the challenges of the sport, and set off to make notable accomplishments in the sport despite any risks that exist.

In any case, many high risk sports are likely to be viewed as unreasonable by those who prefer more traditional sports. That isn't to say some will view it as feasbile or impractical to pursue, but most will understand the dangers and steer clear based on their own vocation. Those sports will continue to remain sports even if many view them as too dangerous or risky, as it will still have participants willing to work towards meeting their demands and overcoming its risks, to make amazing feats and achievements based on physical and mental prowess.
